title: How many total cases of COVID-19 in the U.S. will The COVID Tracking Project report as of Sunday 12 April 2020?
preds: Continuation of growth rate - limitations on growth from the number of tests.
Hmmmmm, anything less than 77K today will hit the second bucket. Could be possible ;-)

The locations of the areas getting the highest daily percentage increases is moving away from around NY and NJ toward Maryland and Virginia and into the more rural states such as West Virginia, Nebraska, South Dakota and New Mexico. 
In general the places that have had the highest numbers of cases per million in population are increasing their cases more slowly than the places that have had the lowest number of cases per million. This pattern could suggest that the actions taken to restrict movement are working, or it could mean that because NY has tested a lot more it has found more cases.

Lot depends on today's testing numbers.  My estimate would be 578K by the 12th However there has been a push to drive up testing numbers which have been hampered by shortages. If daily testing numbers go beyond 45K today then that would be an indicator that this has been addressed and make a borderline 600K result by the 12th a possibility  While it would appear to be a certainty it will end in the 500 - 600 range  ~  one cannot fully exclude the possibility of it going over
As of 4/10 pm @ 500K, tracking at ~ 35K/day, so unlikely to exceed 100K in next 48 hours

The last positive number on 4/10/2020 after 4 p.m. was 491,156. (Interestingly, the 4/4/2020 mentioned in the question is off by about 4k from the Covid tracking project number listed on the website. Are they using a different number than I am?)    Anyway, in the last five days the daily increase in cases ranged from 6.65% to 7.90%.   The daily percentage increase has been on a downward trend.  I want to use a 90 % confidence interval, and there are two days left.  So I will use: low: 491,156 x 1.05^2(squared) = 541,499.   high: 491,156 * 1.1^2= 594,298.  The mid-point is 567,898.  More than six days ago the changes were all in the double digits.  There is a slight risk those higher percentages could return, but after five days I think it is only a slight change. Post-prediction note:  I think I may have misread the question.  The question says: the outcome will be determined using data from The COVID Tracking Project for Sunday 12 April 2020 as of 4:00PM ET on Monday 13 April under "Positive".   Is there a delay in processing the data collected prior to 4 p.m. that will change the number published on Sunday at 4 p.m.?  If so, how much?  There is no information relating a delay in processing.  There is a note on the Covid website that said some data arrives after 4 p.m., which is included in the next day's totals.  Yet, this seems irrelevant since the cut-off is 4 p.m. on Sunday.   The confusing part is the mention of 4 p.m. on Monday.  Why mention it if we are not going to use Monday's numbers?  Why 4 p.m.?  I realize that the GJP employees probably take weekends off like the rest of the world.  If the question was going to resolved on Monday when the webmaster comes into work, why mention 4 p.m.?   -- unless we are using Monday's published numbers and not Sundays.  Just curious, is anyone else confused by this?  or just me? If there is another day, Monday, to be included and my numbers change substantially.   The 5 percent low number now becomes 568,574 and the high number becomes 653,728.  So, the new mid-point is 611,151.  I also would have computed new numbers using 8 and 8.5 percent since I only used 10 because it the highest possible number and still yielded a midpoint well within the third range.  The new  high number after 3 days using 8% and 8.5% are 622,494 and 627,348, respectively. the new mid-points would be in the range of 597,594. or a bit less.  I also would have tried other 80 percent and 70 percent ranges to see if I could narrow the likely high and low numbers further.  
At 7.5 percent, the average is 610,611.   At 7.43 percent, which is the mean of the percentages, I get 566,853 after 2 days, and 608,970 after 3 days using just 491,156 to compute the projected number. Therefore, my new prediction would be something like 0 45, 55, 0, ... if Monday were the day. Anyway, I will assume that Sunday is the last day. It's easy to make a highly confident guess here, but, the US is only testing at 100K a day whereas Germany is testing at 100k a day with a population that is roughly a quarter the size of the US. The US is punching well below our weight and should be testing on par with Germany which would put us at 400K test a day. And, given our plethora of labs and human capital, the fact that we are not testing at 1-2 million a day is just lack of determination and leadership.

I think the testing capacity is going to limit the number of reported cases and therefore the number of daily new reports will not change much from the number of reported cases over the past few days. The number is not going to reduce as the USA has not yet hit it's peak, that means I feel it is highly likely that the number will increase daily at the USA capacity rate (30-35K per day).  The number of confirmed cases could go beyond 600K if the USA can increase testing capacity but I feel they are unlikely to be able to do this to any significant degree in a couple of days.
Both testing rates and confirmed cases have grown in a pretty narrow nominal range for the last ten days. It seems unlikely to me that a dramatic shift in those rates occurs in the next two days.
Adjusted forecast based on rate change. Even more confident that the number of total cases will fall into the selected range.

In order to increase above 600,000 the daily numbers would need to increase by 50%

slight acceleration in the last 24 hours but within the overall perameter to be likely less than 600,000

The USA has currently carried out approximately 2.35 million tests over a period of about one month, 78,000 tests per day. Approximately 20% of these have come back positive. I therefore expect a further 234,000 tests to be carried out over the next 3 days, 20% of which will be positive = 46,800 further positive tests. The latest data for the USA is a total of 468,566 positive cases.  I therefore predict the number of cases to be around 515,366 cases on April 12th. It would seem very unlikely that the reported cases will fall into a higher bracket because the number of cases reported will be limited by the amount of tests that can be done not by the actual number of cases in the population. As a side note... All around the world the tests themselves seem to give a lot of false negatives.  As most people tested are displaying the correct symptoms (i.e. have a positive clinical diagnosis) I would expect tests to confirm significantly more than the 20-25% that seems to be the norm in all countries.  This suggests one of two things is happening..... 1, doctors are rubbish at diagnosis (unlikely) or 2, the tests give a very high proportion of false negatives.  My money is on the latter!  The actual case rate is not the subject of this question though, I only include this for those interested in the the testing accuracy side of things.
Updating based on most recent release.

Based on the average rate of increase over the past week, the expected range on April 12 would be 566,000 to 588,000.  But the rate of change may increase, so there is some chance the number could exceed 600,000.  Little chance it could top 700,000 but not impossible.

Not fully sure why the figures are seemingly topping out at this stage, I must have slipped in my reading and analysis. Could have sworn we would be seeing 700,000 - 800,000 by April 12th, but for the past week we have been seeing fairly solid 30k increments in positive cases.

My previous estimates were based on erroneous thinking. I do not see any proof that the current trend should reverse itself, resulting in a dramatic increase in percentage of positive cases. I have recalculated my values based on much tighter parameters, and I do not see realistic scenarios where the number of positive cases would exceed 600k. That would require a roughly 10% increase per day from now until 12 April, which is unlikely.  Much more likely is that the increase will be in the 7-9% range. In these scenarios, the results on 12 April would be as follows:  (i) after a 7% cumulative increase: ~ 554k
(ii) after a 9% cumulative increase: ~ 597k There is a chance that the number of positive cases could exceed 600k, but that would require a significant uptick from now until 12 April, which seems inconsistent with the current trend.  My prediction is that the number of positive cases on 12 April will be approximately 575k.
Based upon testing rates and positive test ratio.

Here is how I came up with my estimate.  Since 1 April, the daily percentage change in positive cases has increased between the parameters of 14% (on the high end) and roughly 8% (on the low end). Therefore, these parameters are my expected values for the next few days. The data does not support any radical deviation from these parameters, so this is the basis for my calculations. We begin with 423,222 positive cases as of 8 April. We expect a value in the range of an 8-14% increase from this value. So, on the low end, we expect the 9 April report to be roughly 457k, and on the high end, approximately 482k. In the last few days (starting around 5 April) we have seen the percentages fall into the single-digit range, so we would expect that trend to continue, although I have accounted for a sudden uptick in my calculations. Realistically, whatever that actual percentage change is, it should only be within the 8-14% range - not significantly lower or higher. With those parameters set, it is only a matter of simple calculation, which I will not go through here. Suffice it to say, even a low-end estimate puts the number of positive cases above 600k, and a high-end estimate puts the number below 700k.  I did allow for the number of positive cases to be in the 500-600k range, because it is possible that the percentage change could keep declining. It is much more unlikely that this change will spike upwards. But I have a strong confidence in the selected range, and I expect that the actual number will somewhere between 625k to 642k.

There are 432k cases today (9 April) with a doubling rate of 8 days. This would give you around 560k cases by Sunday. However, you have the possibility of more cases in case suddenly they discover a number of previously unreported cases, improved testing, etc.

I have been using the following model in forecasting covid-19 in GJO and GJP2. It has been difficult to estimate the slowing down of the covid-19 outbreaks in different countries especially when the deaths and infected cases are still experiencing exponential growth with short doubling times. From the few examples, slowing down of the outbreaks appeared 2 to 3 weeks after effective lockdowns have been applied.  Recently Google published Google Mobility Reports [1] based on analysis of the location data of cell phones worldwide. It compared movements for several activities against a baseline before the outbreak. This allows us to identify the timeline of the lockdown. Modeling Scheme:
1.	Use relative Workplaces mobility trend line to identify the start of an effective lockdown (T0)
2.	Assume turning point T1 = T0 + 3 weeks. 
3.	Extrapolate cases to T1 using the current doubling time reported by Our World Data [2].
4.	Apply a logistic model by fitting to the existing data and modeled data at the turning point T1.
5.	Extrapolate the model to the closing date in question.
6.	This model will be modified from time to time as the date gets closer to T1 to see if the above parameters and assumption have been violated. For the US, the turning point is 16 April.  The current doubling time for infected cases is 7 days. Model prediction for total deaths on 12 April is 610k.  Note that 12 April is earlier than the turning point of 16 April.  The forecast total cases are just from using the doubling time. If doubling time of 6, 8 and 9 days are used, the total cases are 675k, 568k and 536k, respectively.  Since it appears that the US outbreaks are slowing down, it is more likely to have doubling times of 8-9 days versus 6.  [1]  https://www.google.com/covid19/mobility/
[2]  https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus#we-need-to-be-careful-in-interpreting-the-case-fatality-rate-of-an-ongoing-outbreak

The doubling time for cases in most of the heaviest hit states seems to be stabilizing, for example, as of April 5 here are estimates for the doubling rates based on a moving window of 3 days: 
NY ~ 7.8
NJ ~ 6
MI ~ 6.6
CA ~ 7.4
LA ~ 5.6
FL ~ 7.5
PA ~ 4.6 NY alone accounts for more than a third of the total cases, and together these states account for more than two thirds. 
- If these doubling rates (1/doubling time) stay the same (they should decrease), then the total number of cases, a week out, from the above states should be ~2.6 times more. 
- If you factor in a reduction in the doubling rate, of about 30% on average over the week, then you get a doubling, almost exactly.

The polynomial arrived at had about 5% error creating a range of cases between 685K and 751K.  Understanding that NY's trend is flattening somewhat I am going to be more optimistic and lean towards the lower end of that range more than would be proportional.

Took a week to double in last week. Averaging about 30,000 a day for last week but distancing may be having an effect.  Not at top of curve according to two prominent models. Oxford and Imperial. More ‘hotspots’ coming.

I am assuming that the pattern (aka curve) will be similar to that in other countries, with the difference that the USA is continent sized and needs to be viewed as not just one big hot spot but multiple regional hotspots. Looking each state as if it is a hot spot (which is the best I can do with the data at hand) there are no hotspots that appear to be at the stage of the spread where the daily increase in infections rate is as high as has been typical at the take point in other places. In hotspots outside the US daily rate of increases in infections have been 40% to 50% which have declined to around 25% a day until lockdowns (stay-at-home) policies have been put in place, After a fairly steady 25% daily increase before a lockdown, about two to three weeks after the lockdown (i.e. when the lockdown has had time to work) the daily percentage increase starts to drop, but (because the total number of case is still getting bigger) the number of daily new cases continues to rise by a similar number each day for around another week or ten days, during this stage the typical daily percentage increase drops from 25% to 10%. After that stage (as the full effect of the lockdown comes into effect with R now being below 1) the daily percentage continues to drop, (but hovers around the 10% for several days) and then actual number of new cases per day starts to drop.  Outside the US this pattern was seen. China was well ahead of most countries, and Wuhan was ahead of the rest of China. So when Wuham had reduced its daily rate of increase to 10% other parts of China had higher daily percentage rates, and then Wuhan got down to almost zero while other parts of China still had higher daily rates, until the whole of China had very small increases daily (with a total of about 80,000 cases) but most of the rest of the world had few cases (5,000 or so so) but a very high daily increase percentage, this  5,000 expended to over a million in March, while the total in China remained fairly static.  Unless the data is wrong (or I have misunderstood it) in the USA the over 25% a day increases have passed in all States. The places with the highest daily percentage increases are smaller places and I don't see them making a significant difference to over all total.   So for this week the likely daily increase in new cases to likely to be between 35,000 and 22,000 or 200,000 to 150,000 (as of today) to between 480,000 and 635,000
Interested in watching the virus spread but I think the numbers may be under reported due to the lack of testing kits and the ability to get results quickly through the week

Growth rates have been coming down/stabilizing, tests per day seem to be rather stable (except outlier on the 4th of April). Daily percentage growth rate dropped to 8.7% as of 05 April - if that trend continues (-1% per day decline of growth rate and then stabilizing at 4%; this is what was observed in Italy, where growth rates went to after the lock-down and stabilized at ~4% now), we could get to below 500k. If 8.7% was outlier and we move back to 12.4% increase per day (5 day average) we will land more in the 700-800k range. Many states are in lock-down now, so high increase in growth rates seems less likely. Distribution quite wide so far, will require frequent updating once we get more data.

Looking at the data provided, the number of positive cases has multiplied by about 2.5 to 3 every week for the past few weeks.  This suggests that we should end up in the 700,000 to 1,000,000 range. Serious measures have been taken recently, but it should take weeks for the effect of those to show up in the data and start decreasing the number of cases, while increased testing should increase the number of confirmed positive cases.
Variations in testing availability may skew some of this data

Added a bunch of uncertainty to my last forecast due to lack of clarity on how much the US, and various states can ramp up their testing capabilities.

First guess: 
- Number of cases is 332000 as of April 5. 
- Doubling time based on last 3 days of data is about 5.7 days, and the trend for the doubling time is increasing at a rate of about 0.2 days per day.  
- The number of cases could increase significantly if testing capabilities increase and as more tests are conducted, or slow down if not (as the social distancing measures start  to work - see above point). 
- Let's say, roughly that that the doubling time will be between 4 and 8 -- then most of the mass should be between 600000 cases and 1.1 million cases. 
- If doubling time stays constant at 5.7 days ---> ~770K 
- If doubling time improves by 0.2 days every day --> ~720K
- If doubling time improves by 0.4 days every day --> ~680K
- If doubling time deteriorates by 0.1 days every day -->  ~816K
- If doubling time deteriorates by 0.1 days every day -->  ~860K
- New York is slowing down and it accounts for about a third of the cases.

I'm using a crude pseudo-model [1] that takes the average logistic (S-) curve of all countries (from ECDC via OurWorldInData.org [2]), starting from each country's first day of 100 cases, using current U.S. data from The COVID Tracking Project to place it on the curve using the average of the last three days' growth rates, and projecting the curve from that point forward to April 12th. I then average the last three days of April 12th projections to establish a my official mean count. I do this to average out the volatility of growth rates from one day to the next. Because I'm only taking an average of the last three days instead of the past seven days, the model may undercount when using data from Sat/Sun/Mon and overcount when using data from Tue/Wed/Thu due to known weekly variability on those days [3], but hopefully this balances out some of that discrepancy while still using very recent data. To find the probabilities for each bin, I then set a max upward bound of four times the difference of the projected mean and the latest count, a very rough calculation based on eyeballing the prediction intervals of Fotios Petropoulos' projections from early March [4]. For example, today's projection shows a mean of 663,793 U.S. cases by April 12th. After subtracting today's count (332,308) and multiplying by 4, the upper bound then is 1,989,734 cases. Upper bound should be ~3 standard deviations, so I calculate the standard deviation by dividing the difference between the upper bound and the mean by 3 for a final standard deviation of 441,980. (Because I'm taking the difference between projected mean and today's count, this standard deviation will naturally narrow as we get closer to April 12th, honing in on a particular bin.) I then calculate probabilities for bins based on that standard deviation and a lower bound standard deviation that creates a non-normalized distribution, given the exponential probabilities in the upper bound. When calculating probabilities against the bin ranges defined in this forecasting question, I get the following: Less than 500,000: 7%
to 600,000: 21%
to 700,000: 25%
to 800,000: 9%
to 900,000: 8%
to 1,000,000: 7%
to 1,100,000: 6%
to 1,200,000: 5%
Over 1,200,000: 11% To get my final forecast, I "extremize" by 20% to account for likely conservativeness in model:
7%, 20%, 28%, 8%, 8%, 7%, 6%, 5%, 11% I'll update my model and forecast daily. Crowd:

The rate of increase is slowing. My model predicts 568k, but small changes can make a big difference with exponentials, so there's some scatter included.

Growth in new cases has been slowing in recent days, roughly consistent with the increased social distancing.  There's enough social interaction still happening, even in areas with significant outbreaks, that it seems unlikely the growth in new cases will actually turn negative.  Depending on assumptions, I find it pretty easy to get numbers in the 650k to 800k range.
